channel.title: Generic FunOrb Loader
channel.description:
[b]edit: wasn't sure where to post this[/b]
I thought this community needs a "push" in the right direction,
maybe we may see some new funorb hacks brew on the occasion?
just launch the application from the command line using
java in.arcanum.funorb.Main <gamename(String)> <servernumber(int)>
e.g. [code] java in.arcanum.funorb.Main chess 1 java in.arcanum.funorb.Main armiesofgielinor 3 [/code]
Hint: find the game name by clicking on the game then looking at the address bar at the top
NOTE: the server number must be a VALID server number for the game, this loader parses their server numbers, so they do not always start at 1, just click the game and then click "Server List" just above and choose a server number!

item.title: Generic FunOrb Loader
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“devilshelper, post:26, topic:258376”]I fail at bcel and reflection.

Someone should add that to the source. And make it so there is a gui popup with all the fields and their values. That should create a better base for hacking? And I would like to see some of the values of things :)[/quote]

Grab ReflectionBuddy from the cherokee SVN:

SourceForge

Cherokee

Download Cherokee for free. Cherokee is a fully extensible and scriptable automation engine for any and all java applets. To make it work for your favorite java applet the most you have to do is write is two classes.


And it will pop up a GUI with all variables and their values. You can change most of them too.

Read full topic

item.title: Generic FunOrb Loader
item.dc:creator: @Victory Victory
item.description:
@Victory wrote:

Oh wow, this makes me feel stupid. I was spending like 2 hours in 010 trying to figure out the pack200 file for Arcanists. I now realize that this is not the client files. The question is now for me: what other projects should I try that would get me into making game servers on my own. This may be a little off topic, but up until now communities like rune-server have discouraged me from working on game servers from jagex games, but this community has given me much hope. Every topic that I see is very knowledgeable.

Read full topic

item.title: Generic FunOrb Loader
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

@Fat Cookies, it uses regex to match that pattern in the HTML file of the game page,
http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/regex/package-summary.html

then i use the Matcher (also in the regex package) to select what i want from the pattern, i group each part togeather using ( )

for example, matcher.group(1) would return the name of the applet, matcher.group(2) the id of the applet, and so on.

Read full topic

item.title: Generic FunOrb Loader
item.dc:creator: @Ace Ace
item.description:
@Ace wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:7, topic:258376”]Pattern regex0 = Pattern.compile("<applet name=\"(.+)\"\\s+id=\"([^>]*)\"\\s+archive=\"([^\\s]+)\"", Pattern.CASE_INSENSITIVE | Pattern.UNICODE_CASE); Matcher regexMatcher0 = regex0.matcher(HTML); if(regexMatcher0.find()) properties.put("archive", regexMatcher0.group(3)); try { Pattern regex = Pattern.compile("<param name=\"([^\\s]+)\"\\s+value=\"([^>]*)\">", Pattern.CASE_INSENSITIVE | Pattern.UNICODE_CASE);

Can you please Explain how that Finds the Jar File.
The “<applet name=”(.+)"\s+id="([^>]*)"\s+archive="([^\s]+)"" Confuses me.[/quote]http://www.google.com/search?q=regular+expressions

And ollie: nice.

Read full topic

Can you please Explain how that Finds the Jar File.
